SEARCH
Package danogl.components

Class RendererComponent

java.lang.Object
danogl.components.RendererComponent
All Implemented Interfaces:
Component
public class RendererComponent extends Object implements Component
Encapsulates the rendering properties and abilities of a GameObject
Author:
Dan Nirel

  • Constructor Summary

    Description

    Construct the component for the given GameObject.

  • Constructor Details

    • RendererComponent

      public RendererComponent(GameObject gameObject, Renderable renderable)
      Construct the component for the given GameObject. Sets its Renderable to be the supplied argument.

  • Method Details

    • update

      public void update(float deltaTime)
      Description copied from interface: Component
      When a GameObject is assigned this component, it calls this method in every update
      Specified by:
      update in interface Component
      Parameters:
      deltaTime - the time, in seconds, since the previous update

    • render

      public void render(Graphics2D g, Vector2 topLeftCorner, Vector2 dimensions)
      Render the GameObject
      Parameters:
      g - the graphics object used for rendering
      topLeftCorner - the GameObject's position
      dimensions - the GameObject's dimensions

    • getRenderable

      public Renderable getRenderable()
      Returns:
      The current Renderable.

    • setRenderable

      public void setRenderable(Renderable renderable)
      A setter for the image.
      Parameters:
      renderable - the new image. Can be null.

    • getRenderableAngle

      public float getRenderableAngle()
      The angle at which the renderable is rendered, relative to its center, in degrees, counterclockwise. Note that this angle does not affect collisions, only rendering.

    • setRenderableAngle

      public void setRenderableAngle(float renderableDegreesCounterclockwise)
      Set the angle at which the renderable is rendered, relative to its center, in degrees, counterclockwise. Note that this angle does not affect collisions, only rendering; it is therefore preferable to use a non-zero angle only for objects whose width and height are similar or for non-colliding objects.

    • isFlippedHorizontally

      public boolean isFlippedHorizontally()
      Is the image flipped horizontally

    • setIsFlippedHorizontally

      public void setIsFlippedHorizontally(boolean isFlippedHorizontally)
      Set whether the image should be flipped horizontally

    • isFlippedVertically

      public boolean isFlippedVertically()
      Is the image flipped vertically

    • setIsFlippedVertically

      public void setIsFlippedVertically(boolean isFlippedVertically)
      Set whether the image should be flipped vertically

    • getOpaqueness

      public float getOpaqueness()
      The opaqueness of this object. See setOpaqueness(float).

    • setOpaqueness

      public void setOpaqueness(float opaqueness)
      Sets the object's opaquness. 1 for opaque, 0 for invisible, values in between for degrees of transparency.

    • fadeIn

      public void fadeIn(float fadeInTime)
      Gradually increase the GameObject's opaqueness over the supplied length of times, in seconds. After this time the opaqueness will be 1.

    • fadeOut

      public void fadeOut(float fadeOutTime)
      Gradually decrease the GameObject's opaqueness over the supplied length of times, in seconds. After this time the opaqueness will be 0.

    • fadeIn

      public void fadeIn(float fadeInTime, Runnable afterFadeIn)
      Gradually increase the GameObject's opaqueness over the supplied length of times, in seconds. After this time the opaqueness will be 1.
      Parameters:
      afterFadeIn - a function to execute when the fadeIn is over

    • fadeOut

      public void fadeOut(float fadeOutTime, Runnable afterFadeOut)
      Gradually decrease the GameObject's opaqueness over the supplied length of times, in seconds. After this time the opaqueness will be 0.
      Parameters:
      afterFadeOut - a function to execute when the fadeOut is over
